trustfund:
TF025395-PHRD-THIRD INLAND WATERWAYS (BANK-EXECUTED),TF025699-PHRD-THIRD INLAND WATERWAYS (RECIPIENT-EXECUTED),TF038968-CHINA - 3RD INLAND WATERWAYS
            PROJECT - SUPERVISION

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Inland Waterways
            Project for China are as follows: outcome was satisfactory,
            risk to the development outcome was low or negligible, the
            Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also rated as satisfactory. Some of the
            lessons learned included: 1) there is an increasing demand
            for inland water transportation in China especially for
            low-value commodities in large consignments from and to
            destinations alongside or near a river or inland waterway.
            Users of China's inland waterways are aware of the
            benefit of using larger vessels for such cargo and responded
            positively to improvements in inland waterway
            infrastructures that promote their use. The study on the
            development of container shipping on the Xiangjiang
            concluded that with the standardization of vessels,
            improvement to navigation channels, up-to-date handling
            facilities and terminals, effective inter-modal connections
            (road and rail access/linkages), and strong government
            support, container shipping on China's inland waterways
            can reach Europe's inland waterways share of 40 percent
            total container traffic transported; 2) as was found in
            previous inland waterway projects, cost recovery mechanisms
            are rarely sufficient to cover all costs, but these costs
            are small compared to other modes in either absolute terms
            or in proportion to traffic handled. In general, permanent
            government subsidies for transport infrastructure should be
            avoided but inland waterway systems are somewhat
            exceptional: for the most part they are appropriately
            treated as public goods recovered through taxes and vessel
            registration fees. In this light, and given inland waterways
            greater energy efficiency and smaller environmental
            footprint, this national policy appears appropriate; and 3)
            the Bank's operational policy on safety of dams (OP
            4.37) requires reviews of the investigation, design, and
            construction of the dam and start of operation by an
            independent panel of experts where the dam is more than 15
            meters in height. This requirement did not apply to the
            Zuzhou Dam which had a designed height of 10 meters.
            Nevertheless a Dam Safety Panel for the Project was formed.
